snippet: After the Greek and French elections, growth is now a priority in Europe, but significant change may depend on how far Germany is willing to budge from austerity.
abstract: Emphasis across Europe, even in the austerity heartland of Germany, has shifted to the very real problem of growth in wake of raucous elections that nearly destroyed the political establishment in Greece and ended 17 years of conservative reign in France. Photos (M)

byline.original: By NICHOLAS KULISH; Alan Cowell contributed reporting from Paris, Elisabetta Povoledo from Rome, and Raphael Minder from Madrid

lead_paragraph: BERLIN -- In the volatile aftermath of raucous elections, which nearly destroyed the political establishment in Greece and ended 17 years of conservative reign in France, the emphasis across Europe, even in the austerity heartland of Germany, has shifted to the very real problem of growth for the stagnant Continent. But there are few ready answers for how to turn around recessionary economies during a major sovereign debt crisis, and it will take weeks of contentious wrangling to determine whether the Germans can be pressed to make more than cosmetic changes to their focus on fiscal discipline for all.

headline.main: After Votes, Europe Focuses on Growth, but Is Divided on Path Ahead
